line_1: And, though her fops are wond'rous civil,
line_2: He thinks her ugly as the devil.

line_1: And Maggy — na, na! we'll be civil,
line_2: A vilipend tongue is the devil,

line_1: These I cou'd bear; but not a Rogue so civil,
line_2: Whose Tongue can complement you to the Devil.

line_1: And thought he was exceeding civil,
line_2: Tho' wrong, she knew he meant no evil,
I'll give thee — to the devil,

line_1: 'Twas yours, had you been honest, wise, or civil;
line_2: Now ev'n go court the Bishops — or the Devil.

line_1: "Z—ds! damn the Lock! 'fore Gad, you must be civil!
line_2: And thus broke out — "My Lord, why, what the Devil?

line_1: For well-bred folks are ne'er so civil,
line_2: As when they wish you at the D—I.
